cm3038.search.informed

Class BestFirstSearchProblem

  • java.lang.Object
    • cm3038.search.SearchProblem
      • cm3038.search.informed.BestFirstSearchProblem
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Sq8Problem

    public abstract class BestFirstSearchProblem
extends SearchProblem
    This is a specialised SearchProblem for informed searches. This class contains most ingredients of an informed search problem. In most cases you can simply extend this class to create your own specialised problem of informed search. However, you still need to supply the evaluation function (and heuristic if needed).
    Author:
    kit

    • Field Detail

      • goalState

        public State goalState
        Most informed searches need to compute the distance between the current state and the goal. So I am storing the goal state into this attribute. You can always refer to this attribute and check if you have reached the goal state. Note that this attribute is only defined in the BestFirstSearchProblem class but not in its SearchProblem superclass.

    • Constructor Detail

      • BestFirstSearchProblem

        public BestFirstSearchProblem(State start,
                              State goal)
        Construct a BestFirstSearchProblem object. Note that BestFirstSearchProblem is an abstract class. So you will not directly create a BestFirstSearchProblem object but from one of its concrete subclasses. This constructor is expected to be invoked from a concrete subclass.
        Parameters:
        start - The initial state.
        goal - The goal state.

    • Method Detail

      • search

        public Path search()
        This is a specialised version of search tailored for informed search. It takes care of repeating states. The initial and goal states should be defined when the BestFirstSearchProblem object is created. This method simply starts the search. For debugging purpose, it prints a message for every 1000 nodes explored.
        Overrides:
        search in class SearchProblem
        Returns:
        The path to the goal. Or null if there is no solution.

      • addChild

        protected void addChild(java.util.List<Node> fringe,
                        Node childNode)
        Adding a child node into the fringe list. We sort the fringe by the evaluation function values of the nodes. This method can be customised to change the order of expanding children nodes. In best-first search, this the child with the lowest f(n) score is placed at the head of the queue.
        Overrides:
        addChild in class SearchProblem
        Parameters:
        fringe - A list of Node.
        childNode - The child Node to add into the fringe.

      • evaluation

        public abstract double evaluation(Node node)
        The evaluation function is to be supplied. You must supply this in a concrete subclass. Note that the BestFirstSearchProblem class only requires the evaluation function (i.e. f(n)). If you are implementing A* search, your evaluation function may need a heuristic function too (i.e. h(n)), which you also have to supply. A pure best-first search does not care about the existence of an h(n). In this method, you can use the Node.getCost() method to get the cost of the path up to the node.
        Parameters:
        node - The node to consider.
        Returns:
        The score of the node. The lower the score is, the better the node.
